title: Optimizing Brain Health
content: Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. The role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration. Blood pressure: an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk. Possible mechanisms by which exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer’s disease. Possible brain benefits of sauna. The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk. How exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health. Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits. The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength. Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward.

title: Impact of COVID-19 on Sleep
content: The COVID-19 pandemic has impacted sleep in 3 ways: The amount that people are sleeping, the timing of the sleep, and dreaming. Total sleep time had increased across the entire country by ~20%. Social “jet lag” had decreased. Subjective sleep quality had decreased in a subset of people. People were going to bed about 30 minutes later and waking up about 50 minutes later the next morning. People have been reporting having more dreams since the pandemic began.

title: Importance of Dreaming for Emotional Health
content: Dreaming has increased during the coronavirus pandemic due to two reasons: Timing of sleep and dreaming allows for the purging negative emotion or stress. REM sleep is typically associated with dreaming. These are the dreams we think of as narrative-based, emotionally-filled, bizarre, hallucinogenic, dreams. One of the principle functions of rapid eye movement sleep that we now have understood is that it seems to provide a form of overnight therapy. REM sleep tries to take the sharp edges off difficult experiences so that when you come back the next day without feeling as emotional as you did about those events the day before.

title: Importance of REM Sleep
content: REM sleep is emotional first aid. It’s not time that heals all wounds. It’s actually time during REM sleep and dreaming that provides this emotional convalescence. Sleep is responsive—it’s what we call homeostatically regulated, but also homeostatically reflexive. If something happens during the day that requires more of a specific stage of sleep, then sleep will respond by giving the brain a little bit more of that sleep to deal with it.

title: Impact of Alcohol on Sleep Quality
content: Alcohol consumption can negatively impact sleep quality. Heart rate variability gets crushed, resting heart rate goes up by 10-25%, respiratory rate is up two breaths per minute, and core body temperature is up half a degree. Alcohol is a sedative, it can make your sleep more fragmented and decrease the amount of REM sleep that you get.

title: Sleep's Impact on the Immune System
content: Sleep improves immune function. There is a very intimate association between your sleep health and your immune health. Individuals getting less than seven hours of sleep a night are almost three times more likely to become infected by the rhinovirus (common cold). A large prospective study of over 50,000 women found that women who were sleeping 5 hours or less were 70% more likely to develop pneumonia.

title: Determinants of Deep Sleep and REM Sleep
content: How much deep sleep you need/get is determined by how long you’ve been awake and only a little bit on the basis of your circadian rhythm. REM sleep is much more powerfully determined by the circadian time of night and is less determined by how long you’ve been awake.

title: Pros and Cons of Napping
content: Naps as short as 17 minutes can produce learning and memory benefits. And you can some benefit from a cardiovascular standpoint as well. Downside of naps is that it can take away which is sleep pressure which could exacerbate nighttime sleep issues.

title: Sleep Hygiene Tips
content: Regularity: Going to bed at the same time, waking up at the same time. Light: Getting lots of darkness at night because we are a dark-deprived society (and making sure you get daylight during the first half of the day). Temperature: You need to get cool to get to sleep. Walk it out: Don’t lie awake in bed because trains your brain to be triggered by your bed and force you awake because you have a learned association. Alcohol/caffeine: Avoid alcohol and caffeine too close to bedtime.

title: Improving Sleep Performance
content: Building a routine into your sleep schedule can be beneficial. This routine might include light stretches, meditation, and putting away all phones and gadgets. If you are struggling with sleep, remove all clock faces from your bedroom. This can help reduce anxiety. Technology, especially phones, can cause 'anticipatory anxiety' and result in 'sleep procrastination'. Setting manageable goals can also help improve sleep performance. These tips are for people without a sleep disorder. If you do have an actual sleep disorder (insomnia, apnea, etc.) you need to get help from a physician.

title: Understanding Sleep Chronotypes
content: Your sleep chronotype refers to whether you are a morning person, an evening person, or somewhere in between. Sleep science breaks it into 4 categories: Extreme morning types, Morning types, Middle evening types, Extreme evening types. There is a significant degree of heritability and a collection of genes that will determine, to a degree, your chronotype. Your innate chronotype can still be twisted/contorted by non-genetic forces such as modern social norms, light exposure, technology, etc.

title: Night Terrors in Kids
content: Night terrors are typically where people (mostly kids) wake up with a terrible sense of dread and fear. The night terror events seem to happen during deep non-REM sleep (i.e., dreamless sleep) rather than during REM sleep. When a child spends an extended time being awake or miss a nap (i.e., they are exhausted), they will typically then have a homeostatic increase in the amount of deep sleep. This therefore means that the probabilistic likelihood of them having one of these night terrors is increased as a consequence.

title: Addressing Errors in Sleep Research
content: There are several errors in sleep research that need to be addressed. These include the association between sleep and cardiovascular disease, the relationship between short sleep and cancer risk, the relationship between sleep deprivation and depression, the relationship between sleep loss and cardiovascular disease, the relationship between sleep loss/short sleep and cardiac arrests, the relationship between long sleep and mortality risk, and the claim that the WHO classified any form of nighttime shift work as a probable carcinogen.
